General Syntax

On this page

Literals ​

Baseline Feature
Version: 0.1.2
Status: ✅ Implemented
Test: 00_base_feats/01_literals.vx

Overview ​

Literals are fixed values written directly in source code. Vex supports integer, floating-point, boolean, string, and byte literals.

Integer Literals ​

Decimal Integers ​

Basic decimal numbers without prefix:

rust
let zero = 0;
let answer = 42;
let million = 1_000_000;  // Underscores for readability

Default Type: i32
Regex: [0-9][0-9_]*

Hexadecimal Integers ​

Prefix: 0x or 0X

rust
let color = 0xFF;           // 255
let flags = 0x1A2B;         // 6699
let byte_val = 0xFF;        // 255

Regex: 0[xX][0-9a-fA-F][0-9a-fA-F_]*

Binary Integers ​

Prefix: 0b or 0B

rust
let bits = 0b1010;          // 10
let mask = 0b11110000;      // 240
let flag = 0b0000_0001;     // 1 (with separators)

Regex: 0[bB][01][01_]*

Octal Integers ​

Prefix: 0o or 0O

rust
let permissions = 0o755;    // 493
let mode = 0o644;           // 420

Regex: 0[oO][0-7][0-7_]*

Type Suffixes ​

Explicit type specification:

rust
let small: i8 = 127;
let unsigned: u32 = 4294967295;
let big: i64 = 9223372036854775807;

Implementation ​

Lexer: vex-lexer/src/lib.rs

rust
// Decimal integer
if let Some(int_val) = text.parse::<i64>().ok() {
    return TokenSpan {
        token: Token::IntLiteral(int_val),
        span: start..self.position,
    };
}

// Hexadecimal: 0xFF
if text.starts_with("0x") || text.starts_with("0X") {
    // Parse hex
}

// Binary: 0b1010
if text.starts_with("0b") || text.starts_with("0B") {
    // Parse binary
}

// Octal: 0o755
if text.starts_with("0o") || text.starts_with("0O") {
    // Parse octal
}

AST: vex-ast/src/expressions.rs

rust
pub enum Expression {
    IntLiteral(i64),
    TypedIntLiteral { value: i64, type_suffix: String },
    BigIntLiteral(String),  // For i128/u128
    // ...
}

Floating-Point Literals ​

Basic Floats ​

Decimal numbers with decimal point:

rust
let pi = 3.14;
let e = 2.71828;
let half = 0.5;

Default Type: f64
Regex: [0-9][0-9_]*\.[0-9][0-9_]*

Scientific Notation ​

Exponential format with e or E:

rust
let large = 1.5e10;         // 15000000000.0
let small = 2.0e-5;         // 0.00002
let sci = 6.022E23;         // Avogadro's number

Regex: [0-9]+\.?[0-9]*[eE][+-]?[0-9]+

Type Suffixes ​

rust
let single: f32 = 3.14;
let double: f64 = 2.718281828;

Implementation ​

Lexer:

rust
if let Some(float_val) = text.parse::<f64>().ok() {
    return TokenSpan {
        token: Token::FloatLiteral(float_val),
        span: start..self.position,
    };
}

AST:

rust
pub enum Expression {
    FloatLiteral(f64),
    // ...
}

Boolean Literals ​

Two values: true and false

rust
let yes = true;
let no = false;
let flag: bool = true;

Type: bool

Implementation:

Lexer: Keywords true and false

rust
"true" => Token::True,
"false" => Token::False,

AST:

rust
pub enum Expression {
    BoolLiteral(bool),
    // ...
}

String Literals ​

Basic Strings ​

Enclosed in double quotes:

rust
let greeting = "Hello, World!";
let empty = "";
let multiword = "The quick brown fox";

Type: string (UTF-8)
Regex: "([^"\\]|\\["\\bnfrt]|\\u[a-fA-F0-9]{4})*"

Escape Sequences ​

SequenceMeaningCodepoint
\"Double quoteU+0022
\\BackslashU+005C
\nNewline (LF)U+000A
\rCarriage returnU+000D
\tTabU+0009
\bBackspaceU+0008
\fForm feedU+000C
\uXXXXUnicode (4 hex)U+XXXX

Examples:

rust
let newline = "line1\nline2";
let tab = "col1\tcol2";
let quote = "He said \"Hello\"";
let path = "C:\\Users\\Admin";
let unicode = "\u0041";  // 'A'

F-Strings (Interpolation) ​

Prefix: f"...{expr}..."

rust
let name = "Alice";
let age = 30;
let msg = f"Hello, {name}! You are {age} years old.";
let calc = f"Result: {5 + 3}";

Implementation:

Lexer:

rust
// F-string: f"Hello {name}"
if self.current_char() == Some('f') && self.peek_char(1) == Some('"') {
    self.advance(); // skip 'f'
    return self.read_string(true); // is_fstring = true
}

// Regular string
if self.current_char() == Some('"') {
    return self.read_string(false);
}

AST:

rust
pub enum Expression {
    StringLiteral(String),
    FStringLiteral(String),  // Parsed, interpolation in codegen
    // ...
}

String Escape Processing: vex-lexer/src/lib.rs

rust
fn unescape_string(s: &str) -> String {
    let mut chars = s.chars();
    let mut result = String::new();

    while let Some(ch) = chars.next() {
        if ch == '\\' {
            match chars.next() {
                Some('n') => result.push('\n'),
                Some('r') => result.push('\r'),
                Some('t') => result.push('\t'),
                Some('b') => result.push('\x08'),
                Some('f') => result.push('\x0C'),
                Some('"') => result.push('"'),
                Some('\\') => result.push('\\'),
                Some('u') => {
                    let hex: String = chars.by_ref().take(4).collect();
                    if let Ok(code) = u32::from_str_radix(&hex, 16) {
                        if let Some(unicode_char) = char::from_u32(code) {
                            result.push(unicode_char);
                        }
                    }
                }
                Some(c) => {
                    result.push('\\');
                    result.push(c);
                }
                None => result.push('\\'),
            }
        } else {
            result.push(ch);
        }
    }
    result
}

Byte Literals ​

Vex uses u8 type for byte/ASCII values (no dedicated char type):

rust
let byte_a: u8 = 97;        // 'a' in ASCII
let byte_newline: u8 = 10;  // '\n'
let byte_null: u8 = 0;      // null byte

Hex representation:

rust
let byte_esc: u8 = 0x1B;    // ESC character
let byte_del: u8 = 0x7F;    // DEL character

Note: No single-quote character literals ('a'). Use u8 with numeric values.

Nil Literal ​

Represents absence of value (unit type):

rust
let nothing = nil;
fn no_return() {
    // implicitly returns nil
}

Type: () (unit)

Implementation:

Lexer:

rust
"nil" => Token::Nil,

AST:

rust
pub enum Expression {
    Nil,
    // ...
}

Type Inference ​

Literals are inferred based on context:

rust
let x = 42;           // i32 (default integer)
let y = 3.14;         // f64 (default float)
let z = true;         // bool
let s = "text";       // string

let a: i64 = 42;      // Explicit i64
let b: f32 = 3.14;    // Explicit f32

Examples from Test ​

From Specifications/Tests/00_base_feats/01_literals.vx:

rust
fn main(): i32 {
    // Integer literals
    let int_decimal = 42;
    assert(int_decimal == 42, "Decimal integer");

    let int_hex = 0xFF;
    assert(int_hex == 255, "Hexadecimal integer");

    let int_binary = 0b1010;
    assert(int_binary == 10, "Binary integer");

    let int_octal = 0o755;
    assert(int_octal == 493, "Octal integer");

    // Float literals
    let float_basic = 3.14;
    assert(float_basic > 3.0, "Basic float");

    let float_exp = 1.5e2;
    assert(float_exp == 150.0, "Float with exponent");

    // Boolean literals
    let bool_true = true;
    let bool_false = false;
    assert(bool_true, "Boolean true");
    assert(!bool_false, "Boolean false");

    // String literals
    let str_basic = "hello";
    assert(str_basic == "hello", "Basic string");

    let str_escaped = "line1\nline2";

    // Byte literals (u8 for ASCII characters)
    let byte_a: u8 = 97;  // 'a' in ASCII
    let byte_zero: u8 = 0;
    assert(byte_a == 97, "Byte literal");

    return 0;
}
